questions.question_text: Which two statements are true concerning Oracle 19c Clusterware-managed application VIPs? (Choose two.)

choices.D: An application VIP can be created with the crsctl utility.
choices.B: Application VIPs do not fail over to surviving cluster nodes when the node hosting the VIP fails.
choices.A: An application VIP is created on the default network by the appvipcfg utility.
choices.C: If an application sends messages to be displayed and sets the DISPLAY variable, then an application VIP is required.
choices.E: An application VIP is created on the interconnect network by the crsctl utility.
Use srvctl stop vip to stop the VIP on host01.
choices.C: Use oifcfg setif to stop the VIP on host01.
choices.B: Use oifcfg setif to start the VIP on host01.
choices.D: Use srvctl modify nodeapps to change the VIP on host01.
choices.A: Use srvctl start vip to start the VIP on host01.

discussion.content:
A. Use srvctl start vip to start the VIP on host01.
 D. Use srvctl modify nodeapps to change the VIP on host01.
E. Use srvctl stop vip to stop the VIP on host01.

Selected Answer: ADE
C is wrong 
A is correct - srvctl stop vip

questions.question_text:
Your four-node cluster runs Oracle 19c Clusterware and supports a mix of RAC databases from Oracle 10g Release 2 to Oracle 19c.
All databases have one or more services defined.
The Oracle 10g Release 2 database clients connect to the database instances using the public VIP.
The Oracle 11g Release 2, 12c Release 1, and 19c clients connect to the database instances using the Single Client Access Name (SCAN).
You must change the public VIPs.
Which three actions must be performed to change the VIPs on host01, the first node in the cluster? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
Administrators can create different categories based on specific attributes and assign different servers to them. This allows for the creation of heterogeneous nodes within a cluster, and facilitates workload isolation and resource agility.

A server may be added to only one category using the crsctl utility. This statement is correct

Selected Answer: AE
A is correct because Oracle Clusterware allows administrators to define different categories and assign nodes to these categories based on the roles or characteristics of the servers.
E is correct because the attributes used to categorize servers can be modified by administrators to suit their specific clustering requirements.
Incorrect statements:

B is incorrect because not all nodes in a cluster must belong to the same Oracle-supplied category; administrators can create custom categories.
C is incorrect because a server can belong to multiple categories.
D is incorrect because while Oracle Clusterware can discover some server attributes automatically, administrators can also manually set and modify these attributes.
F is incorrect because server categories are not limited to nodes running an application server; they can be used for various types of nodes within the cluster.

choices.E: All server attributes used for categorization are administrator modifiable.
choices.B: All nodes in a cluster belong to the same Oracle-supplied category.
choices.D: All server attributes that may be used to determine the server category are discovered automatically by Oracle Clusterware.
choices.F: Server categories can only be used for nodes running an application server.
choices.A: Different nodes in a cluster may belong to separate administrator-defined categories.
choices.C: A server may be added to only one category using the crsctl utility.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about server categorization in Oracle 19c Clusterware? (Choose two.)
Which two statements are true regarding the default service that is automatically created upon PDB creation in a RAC database environment? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
B sure
E: for OCR registration you need to run srvctl

Selected Answer: BE
A, B or B, E?
I think A is wrong - in general I will say "It is uniformly available on all instances" for admin and policy managed databases

B - is correct for sure
E - default service is not registered - I vote E

choices.E: It is not automatically registered in the OCR.
choices.A: It is uniformly available on all instances for administrator-managed databases.
choices.B: It cannot be used to automate the opening of the PDB by the Clusterware.
choices.D: It is created and started on only one instance when using policy-managed database configuration.
choices.C: It is automatically registered in the OCR.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACE
I think ACE

AEF
Since the RAC system allows many users to connect and process database SQL operations concurrently, many resources, such as data blocks and enqueues, are used simultaneously. This situation demands an effective synchronization of the concurrent tasks.

BDE or ADE
i think BDE

correct answers B,D,E beacuse;
Latches and mutexes may only protect access to memory structures if they are accessed by processes in the same instance. In RAC, latches and mutexes are still used, but for global concurrency control, some additional global enqueues are used to provide protection across instances. Oracle requires concurrency control because it is a multi-user system. Single-instance Oracle provides concurrency control:

Latches or mutexes for memory structures
Enqueues for resource control
Buffer cache pins for cache management

Proposed answer is an concept error: mutexes and latches are "intra" instance concurrency control mechanisms. The question is about global concurrency control.
RAC course guide page 7-3 states
Single-instance oracle provides concurrency control through:
- latches or mutexes for memory structures
- enqueues for resource control
- buffer cache pins for cache management
In RAC, structures and resources may be accessed by or modified by a ssession running on any database instance
RAC, therefore, requires additional global concurrency controls to mediate access across instances
- global locks control library and row cache access --> (cursors)
- Global enqueues control resource access
- Cache fusion controls buffer cache access --> (database block buffers)
So correct answer is: AEF

questions.question_text: Which three resources are managed using global concurrency control in an Oracle 19c RAC multi-instance database? (Choose three.)
